units.title: Present Simple vs Present Continuous
units.summary: Present simple is used for habits and facts; present continuous for actions happening now.
rules: Present simple: subject + base verb (he/she/it adds -s).

quiz.explain: Use present continuous: He is going to the office now.

flashcards.back: Subject + base verb (he/she/it adds -s): She works.

units.title: Past Simple
units.summary: Past simple is used for completed actions in the past.

examples.text: She worked at the bank in 2010.

rules: Past simple: subject + past verb (regular verbs add -ed).
Irregular verbs have unique past forms (go → went).

quiz.explain: Use past form: He ate dinner yesterday.

units.title: Present Perfect
units.summary: Present perfect is used for experiences and actions that have relevance to now.

examples.text: She has just finished her homework.

rules: Use for experiences, changes, or actions with present relevance.

quiz.explain: Correct form: She has gone to school.

flashcards.back: have/has + past participle: I have eaten.
Actions with present relevance or experiences.

units.title: Future Simple
units.summary: Future simple is used for predictions, promises, and spontaneous decisions.
rules: Use for decisions made at the moment of speaking.

quiz.explain: Correct form: He will go to school.

flashcards.back: will + base verb: I will work.

units.title: Present Continuous for Future
units.summary: Present continuous can be used to talk about planned future events.

examples.text: I am meeting my friend tomorrow.
She is flying to Paris next week.

rules: Use for fixed arrangements in the near future.

quiz.q: I am go to the cinema tonight.
quiz.explain: Correct form: I am going to the cinema tonight.

flashcards.back: am/is/are + verb-ing: I am meeting them tomorrow.
